                                                    Our 12 Favorite Kids Magazine Subscriptions

                                                    Updated December 15, 2025

                                                    By Ellen Lee

                                                    Ellen Lee is a writer focused on baby and kid gear. She has smashed Cheerios and milk and let them fester in nearly 50 diaper bagsâ€¦ for journalism.

                                                    FYI

                                                    Weâ€™ve added two new favorite magazines: Brainspace and Oyla Junior.

                                                    December 2025

                                                    My kids donâ€™t pay much attention to the mail that arrives daily, but they do perk up every month when they spot their favorite magazine on top of the stack.

                                                    Particularly for a generation that has grown up with screens, thereâ€™s an appealing novelty to the tactile experience of receiving a print magazine in the mail, flipping through it, stumbling across an intriguing headline or picture, ripping out a page (or a poster or collectible cards), and being wowed by a dramatic two-page spread. To this day, my teenage daughterâ€™s walls are decorated with pictures and photographs saved from her favorite childhood magazines. Thatâ€™s just not possible with blink-and-you-might-miss-it social media.

                                                    Not every kid will take to any given title, of course. But for reluctant readers and bookworms alike, a subscription that matches their skills and interests can feel approachable, spark a love for reading, and offer the opportunity to explore a favorite subject â€” or discover new ones.

                                                    Weâ€™ve curated some of our favorites, from long-running classics like Highlights and Ranger Rick to bold newer titles from parent companies ranging from Sports Illustrated to McSweeneyâ€™s (any of them may be available at your local library). An annual subscription can also make a special gift from miles away, connecting the giver to the kid recipient.

                                                    A babyâ€™s first magazine

                                                    Babybug

                                                    An annual subscription delivers nine issues of this baby- and toddler-friendly magazine to your door.

                                                    $36 from Cricket Media
                                                    $40 from Barnes & Noble

                                                    Short and sweet, Babybug is a 20-page, 7-by-6-inch magazine designed for small hands, and itâ€™s one of our favorite gifts for 2-year-olds. Each issue is printed on thick glossy paper, held together without staples, and filled with illustrations that are colorful and cheerful without being overstimulating. The short stories and poems tackle beginner concepts such as putting on clothes, going to the playground, and taking a bath. And as the child grows up, they can graduate to Cricketâ€™s collection of titles, including Ladybug (stories and poems for kids ages 3 to 6) and Cricket (a collection of fiction, poetry, history, science, and the arts for ages 9 to 14).

                                                    An amusing science magazine

                                                    Brainspace

                                                    An annual subscription covers 6 issues of this Canadian science magazine for kids ages 8 to 14.

                                                    $36 from Brainspace Magazine

                                                    Did you know that hippos fling their poop and pee around to attract other hippos? I did not, until my 9-year-old excitedly informed me after reading Brainspace. This compact magazine is about the size of a paperback novel, but each issue is packed with kid-friendly science stories and activities, such as a magic trick that uses algebra to make it seem like you can read your friendâ€™s mind. It also incorporates optional augmented reality: Some of the stories have Zappar codes, which you can scan with your phone to watch a related video or hear music or animal sounds. The digital element is an intriguing touch, but the magazine stands well on its own.

                                                    Science magazines for kids and teens

                                                    Oyla

                                                    This monthly science magazine is for kids ages 12 and up, and is available through an annual subscription, as well as in bundles. You can also download digital copies and listen to its podcast.

                                                    Buy from Oyla

                                                    Oyla Junior

                                                    This version of the monthly science magazine is aimed at kids ages 8 and up.

                                                    $96 from Oyla
                                                    (for 12 months)

                                                    A science magazine for readers ages 12 and up, Oyla is jammed with stories exploring topics such as how the human body processes medicine and why itâ€™s packaged into tablets and pills. Each issue tackles a broad swath of the sciences, including physics, chemistry, computer science, and animals. Though the text is dense, itâ€™s accompanied by intriguing photographs, illustrations, and graphics. Take this fun fact from an article about radar technology: It turns out that carrots donâ€™t boost an otherwise healthy personâ€™s eyesight. According to the October 2024 issue of Oyla, the myth began in 1940, when the British military sought to hide its radar capabilities, telling the public that a fighter pilotâ€™s ability to shoot down enemy aircraft at night was because he ate a lot of carrots.

                                                    Oyla Junior, meant for a slightly younger audience, is similarly jammed with science stories, along with bright graphics, photographs, a comic strip, and crafts â€” such as how to make your own lava lamp.

                                                    An animal loverâ€™s magazine

                                                    Ranger Rick

                                                    An annual subscription covers 10 issues of the wildlife magazine.

                                                    $15 from Ranger Rick

                                                    This long-running science magazine from the nonprofit National Wildlife Federation â€” Ranger Rick has been publishing for more than 50 years â€” is geared toward elementary schoolers and filled with photographs and stories about animals. Kids rescuing animals, animals in your backyard, animal families, you name it. And in each issue, a cartoon Ranger Rick sets off on an adventure, with the comic strip highlighting how humans are impacting wildlife. Thereâ€™s also Ranger Rick Cub for babies and toddlers and Ranger Rick Jr. for kids ages 4 to 7.

                                                    A classic, activity-filled magazine

                                                    Highlights

                                                    This fun monthly magazine comes with a little of everything, from puzzles to recipes.

                                                    $48 from Highlights

                                                    The first issue of Highlights was published more than 75 years ago, and it has since spun off into kids gear, standalone books, and monthly activity subscriptions. But the classic magazine for elementary-school-age kids remains a favorite, with enduring features such as Hidden Pictures, the Goofus and Gallant comic strip, and silly â€œWhatâ€™s Wrong?â€ illustrations. Itâ€™s one of our favorite gifts for 7-year-olds. Each issue is also packed with a smorgasbord of short stories, an advice column, puzzles, craft ideas, and reader artwork. For the younger set, Highlights also offers High Five for preschool-age kids and Hello Magazine for babies and toddlers. You can also subscribe to the bilingual (Spanish and English) High Five BilingÃ¼e.

                                                    A sporty magazine

                                                    Sports Illustrated Kids

                                                    A subscription sends bimonthly issues to the young sports fan.

                                                    $25 from Sports Illustrated Kids

                                                    Sports Illustrated Kids offers athlete profiles, game stats, a comic strip, and collectible posters and player cards for kids ages 8 and up. Although it tends to heavily feature male professional leagues such as the NBA and NFL, it also highlights female athletes (gymnast Simone Biles and tennis phenom Coco Gauff are favorites). And every issue celebrates young, up-and-coming athletes, such as those competing in the Junior Olympics and other â€œfuture stars.â€

                                                    A magazine full of color and fun

                                                    Kazoo

                                                    This magazine publishes quarterly; you can also purchase individual issues, including back issues.

                                                    $60 from Kazoo

                                                    Founded in 2016 through a Kickstarter campaign, Kazoo is aimed at girls ages 5 to 12, but weâ€™ve found that boys this age can also be drawn to it. The only hint that itâ€™s intended for girls is that the characters in its short stories and its profiles of inspiring real-life scientists, artists, and entrepreneurs tend to be girls and women. The magazine, which we also recommend in our gift guide for 9-year-olds, incorporates bright, bold colors and graphics throughout and also includes puzzles, crafts, art, and activities.

                                                    Anyway

                                                    Anyway is published three times a year. You can purchase individual issues, bundles, or an annual subscription.

                                                    Buy from Anyway Mag

                                                    Anyway is a contemporary take on a tween girlâ€™s magazine, with familiar headlines such as â€œ7 Ways to Shake a Bad Moodâ€ and â€œSkincare Products Under $20,â€ but also headier ones such as â€œIn the Know: Consentâ€ and â€œScreens: Straight-Up Facts About Digital Health.â€ One of our picks in our gift guide for tweens, this magazine offers a healthy alternative to an endless social media feed of beauty and style influencers, and it addresses important topics concerning health, relationships, and culture.

                                                    A current-events magazine

                                                    The Week Junior

                                                    This weekly magazine is topical and current, covering news and world events in a kid-friendly way.

                                                    Buy from The Week Junior

                                                    From whatâ€™s popular in arts and entertainment to news updates from around the world, this weekly magazine covers a lot of ground in its 32 pages. Also recommended in our gift guide for tweens, The Week Junior breaks down the news into easily digestible snippets, informing kids ages 8 and up about all thatâ€™s happening in this fast-paced world. It doesnâ€™t skirt tough issues, addressing climate change, natural disasters, politics, and conflicts locally and around the globe. But it also leaves room for fun and inspiring kid-friendly stories, including regular animal features.

                                                    A magazine to explore world history

                                                    Honest History

                                                    A subscription delivers a new magazine every three months. You can also purchase issues individually or in bundles.

                                                    Buy from Honest History

                                                    Honest History is for elementary- and middle-school-age kids who are curious about history and the underpinnings of global events. Each issue dives into a period of time, a place, or a significant milestone, such as World War II, Scandinavia and the Vikings, or western Africa and the history of the gold and salt trade. In addition to beautifully illustrated stories, it offers activities such as coloring pages and word searches. Readers are also encouraged to listen to its podcast and to send in postcards, which it publishes in its blog.

                                                    A magazine that inspires creativity

                                                    Illustoria

                                                    A subscription covers three issues a year. You can also purchase individual issues.

                                                    $16 from Illustoria
                                                    (single issue)
                                                    $40 from McSweeney's
                                                    (three issues)

                                                    As its name implies, Illustoria is a magazine filled with stories and lush illustrations, along with craft ideas, games, jokes, and a heavy dose of inspiration for the imagination. Each issue tackles a theme such as home, the rainforest, and the senses. One of our recommendations in our gift guide for 9-year-olds, Illustoria is a collaboration between McSweeneyâ€™s and the International Alliance of Youth Writing Centers. Young readers have the opportunity to contribute, with each issue inviting kids (up to age 14) to respond to a prompt and submit it for publication.
